title: Thermally Robust 3-D Co-DpyDtolP-MOF with Hexagonally Oriented Micropores: Formation of Polyiodine Chains in a MOF Single Crystal
abstract: A three-dimensional microporous Co-MOF with 5,15-di(4-pyridyl)-10,20-di(4-methylphenyl)porphyrin (DpyDtolP) linker exhibited high thermal stability. The original crystal structure was retained even after drying Co-MOF at 250 °C. The evacuated Co-MOF showed CO
selectivity over N
. Both CO
-captured Co-MOF and I
-captured Co-MOF were structurally characterized. The I
-captured Co-MOF displayed conductivity implying the formation of polyiodine-based molecular wire inside MOF channels.
A new porphyrin-based Co-MOF, [Co(DpyDtolP)]
O (

), composed of DpyDtolP (5,15-di(4-pyridyl)-10,20-di(4-methylphenyl)porphyrin) was prepared in a high yield and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. DpyDtolP is a ditopic N-donor ligand with a large space or gap between the two pyridyl groups at the 5- and 15-positions of the porphyrin backbone. Unlike the pyridyl groups, the 4-tolyl groups in DpyDtolP could not be involved in coordination toward the metal ion. Nevertheless, the presence of these two 4-tolyl groups led to a new infinite three-dimensional framework: Co-MOF (
) with exceptionally high thermal stability at elevated temperature. The single crystals of

text: Pore engineering of porous materials has been a critical issue for generating new functional porous materials in a wide range of applications in materials chemistry.
For example, the selective capture of guest molecules or ions into well-defined open channels of porous materials often leads to sensitive sensing and capturing systems.

In this sense, crystalline zeolitic materials with well-defined framework structures display a unique molecular sieving effect, and in turn, this unique sieving effect makes it possible to develop new drying agents,

In order to expand the capabilities of natural zeolites, artificial zeolites have been sought for a long time. Because of the unique properties of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which include a high surface area,
the functionality of the interior pore,
and the formation of new hybrid zeolitic, porous materials,

MOFs have become mainstream materials in the development of new functional inorganic crystalline porous materials. Applications have been advanced due to using MOFs. These applications include the large storage capacity of nonpolar CH
the selective sorption of quadrupolar CO
the enzyme-mimetic asymmetric catalysis in confined space having a chiral active center;
the heterogeneous catalysis inside catalytic cavities;
and the efficient proton conduction in functional pores.
Additionally, the nano- and microsized MOFs (nMOFs or mMOFs, respectively) have been reported frequently to have promising applications.
In fact, they often demonstrate numerous advantages over both the MOFs and the inorganic nanomaterials.
Their novel and/or enhanced performances are reported in catalysis,
but the homogeneous fabrication of particles is still a major challenge.

Usually, a high temperature stirring method is employed in their construction because it permits the generation of quick ligand-to-metal coordinative interactions while maintaining the crystallinity and stability of these miniaturized MOFs.
Very recently, the MOFs containing porphyrin-bridging ligands are attracting much interest due to their advantages over more commonly employed aromatic polycarboxylate-bridging ligands.
The porphyrin-based MOFs could be utilized for a wide range of advanced applications including selective catalysis,

The large physical dimensions of the porphyrin unit can also lead to high surface functional MOFs with enhanced hydrolytic stability. In this sense, Yaghi and co-workers recently reported on water-stable Zr(IV)-based Zr
The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of MOF-525 and MOF-545 reached 2620 and 2260 m
, respectively. Zhou and co-workers also reported on the water/pH tolerant, (Zr

The PCN-225 displayed an interesting pH-dependent fluorescence in an aqueous medium. Combined with the intrinsic stability of Zr(IV)-based MOFs, these two examples opened up a new class of functional porphyrin-MOFs.
Moreover, the molecular dimension and functionalities of porphyrin-bridging ligands could be systematically varied in a controllable manner through the simple modification of functional groups at the
-position of the porphyrin backbone on demand. Matsunaga and co-workers prepared a Zn-TCPEP MOF where TCPEP is 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-carboxymethylphenyl)ethynyl-porphyrin.
TCPEP had extended substituents at the
The flat geometry of the porphyrin backbone with various substituents at the

-positions was found to be ideal for the construction of MOFs with a wide range of applications. Therefore, we discuss herein the preparation of thermally robust porphyrin-MOF and their microsized crystalline particles with hexagonal pore symmetry from pyridine-substituted porphyrin, 5,15-di(4-pyridyl)-10,20-di(4-methylphenyl)porphyrin (DpyDtolP), and their selective uptake of CO
. Particularly, we thoroughly examined the CO
-containing single crystals of the MOFs in order to investigate the solid-state structures of the CO

molecules captured inside the MOF channels. We did so because the single crystal structures with captured molecules would provide new and important information for the development of better sorbent materials that would otherwise be difficult to obtain. Furthermore, the structural analysis of the MOFs with captured polyiodine chains was investigated.

This crit. review discusses modification of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) in a postsynthetic scheme.  In this approach, the MOF is assembled and then modified with chem. reagents with preservation of the lattice structure.  Recent findings show amide couplings, isocyanate condensations, click' chem., and other reactions are suitable for postsynthetic modification (PSM).  In addn., a no. of MOFs, from IRMOF-3 to ZIF-90, are amenable to PSM.  The generality of PSM, in both scope of chem. reactions and range of suitable MOFs, clearly indicates that the approach is broadly applicable.  Indeed, the rapid increase in reports on PSM demonstrates this methodol. will play an increasingly important role in the development of MOFs for the foreseeable future (117 refs.).
Postsynthetic Methods for the Functionalization of Metal-Organic Frameworks

A review.  The development of postsynthetic methods is discussed for the chem. modification and functionalization of metal-org. frameworks and related coordination polymers.  Emphasis is placed on the chem. approaches that result in the covalent modification of the org. linkers within the metal-org. frameworks.
Metal-Organic Frameworks as A Tunable Platform for Designing Functional Molecular Materials
Wang, Cheng; Liu, Demin; Lin, Wenbin
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A review.  Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), also known as coordination polymers, represent an interesting class of cryst. mol. materials that were synthesized by combining metal-connecting points and bridging ligands.  The modular nature of and mild conditions for MOF synthesis have permitted the rational structural design of numerous MOFs and the incorporation of various functionalities via constituent building blocks.  The resulting designer MOFs showed promise for applications in a no. of areas, including gas storage/sepn., nonlinear optics/ferroelectricity, catalysis, energy conversion/storage, chem. sensing, biomedical imaging, and drug delivery.  The structure-property relations of MOFs can also be readily established by taking advantage of the knowledge of their detailed at. structures, which enables fine-tuning of their functionalities for desired applications.  Through the combination of mol. synthesis and crystal engineering, MOFs thus present an unprecedented opportunity for the rational and precise design of functional materials.
Controlling the Selectivity of Competitive Nitroaldol Condensation by Using a Bifunctionalized Mesoporous Silica Nanosphere-Based Catalytic System
Huh, Seong; Chen, Hung-Ting; Wiench, Jerzy W.; Pruski, Marek; Lin, Victor S.-Y.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

A series of bifunctionalized mesoporous silica nanosphere-based (MSN) heterogeneous catalysts for the nitroaldol (Henry) reaction have been synthesized.  A common 3-[2-(2-aminoethylamino)ethylamino]propyl (AEP) primary group and three different secondary groups, ureidopropyl (UDP), mercaptopropyl (MP), and allyl (AL) functionalities, were incorporated to these mesoporous silica materials by introducing equal amts. of AEP-trimethoxysilane with UDP-, MP-, or AL-trialkoxysilane precursors to our previously reported co-condensation reaction.  Nanospheres were prepd. by mixing the corresponding reactants in the presence of CTAB, NaOH, and H2O and heating to 80° for 30 min; an example compd. thus prepd. was N-(2-aminoethyl)-N'-[3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl]-1,2-ethanediamine polymer with silicic acid (H4SiO4) tetra-Et ester and [3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl]urea.  Structures and relative concns. of the functional groups were detailed by solid-state NMR and other spectroscopic techniques.  The AEP group served as a catalyst, and the other secondary groups provided different noncovalent interactions to reactants and thereby controlled the reaction selectivity.  By varying the secondary group in these bifunctionalized MSN catalysts, the selectivity of a nitroaldol reaction of two competing benzaldehydes reacting with nitromethane was investigated by measuring the molar ratio of the nitroalkene products.  The selectivity of the bifunctionalized MSN catalysts could be systematically tuned simply by varying the physicochem. properties of the pore surface-bound secondary groups, i.e., polarity and hydrophobicity.

The resulting Pt@MOF assemblies serve as effective photocatalysts for H evolution by synergistic photoexcitation of the MOF frameworks and electron injection into the Pt nanoparticles.  Pt@2 gave a turnover no. of 7000, approx. five times the value afforded by the homogeneous control, and could be readily recycled and reused.

American Association for the Advancement of Science

Metal-org. framework-5 (MOF-5) Zn4O(BDC)3 (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) with a cubic three-dimensional extended porous structure adsorbed hydrogen up to 4.5 wt.% (17.2 hydrogen mols. per formula unit) at 78 K and 1.0 wt.% at room temp. and pressure of 20 bar.  Inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy of the rotational transitions of the adsorbed hydrogen mols. indicates two well-defined binding sites (termed I and II), which the authors assoc. with hydrogen binding to zinc and the BDC linker, resp.  Preliminary studies on topol. similar isoreticular metal-org. framework-6 and -8 (IRMOF-6 and -8) having cyclobutylbenzene and naphthalene linkers, resp., gave approx. double and quadruple (2.0 wt.%) the uptake found for MOF-5 at room temp. and 10 bar.
Hysteretic Adsorption and Desorption of Hydrogen by Nanoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
Zhao, Xuebo; Xiao, Bo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
American Association for the Advancement of Science

Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen from nanoporous materials, such as activated C, is usually fully reversible.  The authors prepd. nanoporous metal-org. framework materials with flexible linkers in which the pore openings, as characterized in the static structures, appear to be too small to allow H2 to pass.  The authors observe hysteresis in their adsorption and desorption kinetics above the supercrit. temp. of H2 that reflects the dynamical opening of the windows between pores.  This behavior would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures.
Metal-Organic Frameworks with Exceptionally High Methane Uptake: Where and How is Methane Stored?
Wu, Hui; Simmons, Jason M.; Liu, Yun; Brown, Craig M.; Wang, Xi-Sen; Ma, Shengqian; Peterson, Vanessa K.; Southon, Peter D.; Kepert, Cameron J.; Zhou, Hong-Cai; Yildirim, Taner; Zhou, Wei

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a novel family of physisorptive materials that have exhibited great promise for methane storage.  So far, a detailed understanding of their methane adsorption mechanism is still scarce.  Herein, we report a comprehensive mechanistic study of methane storage in three milestone MOF compds. (HKUST-1, PCN-11, and PCN-14) the CH4 storage capacities of which are among the highest reported so far among all porous materials.  The three MOFs consist of the same dicopper paddle-wheel secondary building units, but contain different org. linkers, leading to cagelike pores with various sizes and geometries.  From neutron powder diffraction expts. and accurate data anal., assisted by grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations and DFT calcns., we unambiguously revealed the exact locations of the stored methane mols. in these MOF materials.  We found that methane uptake takes place primarily at two types of strong adsorption site: (1) the open Cu coordination sites, which exhibit enhanced Coulomb attraction toward methane, and (2) the van der Waals potential pocket sites, in which the total dispersive interactions are enhanced due to the mol. being in contact with multiple "surfaces.".  Interestingly, the enhanced van der Waals sites are present exclusively in small cages and at the windows to these cages, whereas large cages with relatively flat pore surfaces bind very little methane.  Our results suggest that further, rational development of new MOF compds. for methane storage applications should focus on enriching open metal sites, increasing the vol. percentage of accessible small cages and channels, and minimizing the fraction of large pores.

Park, Hye Jeong; Lim, Dae-Woon; Yang, Woo Seung; Oh, Tae-Rog; Suh, Myunghyun Paik

A doubly interpenetrating porous metal-org. framework [Zn4O(TCBPA)2]·19DMA·4H2O (SNU-77) was synthesized from the solvothermal reaction of the extended carboxylic acid tris(4'-carboxybiphenyl)amine (H3TCBPA) and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA).  SNU-77 undergoes single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations during various activation processes, such as room-temp. evacuation, supercrit. CO2 drying, and high temp. evacuation, to afford SNU-77R, SNU-77S, and SNU-77H, resp.  These guest-free MOFs exhibited different fine structures with different window shapes and different effective window sizes at room temp.  Variable-temp. synchrotron single-crystal x-ray analyses reveal that the guest-free structure is also affected by changes in temp.  Despite the different fine structures, SNU-77R, SNU-77S, and SNU-77H show similar gas sorption properties due to the nonbreathing nature of the framework and an addnl. structural change upon cooling to cryogenic gas sorption temp.  SNU-77H exhibits a large surface area (BET, 3670 m2 g-1), a large pore vol. (1.52 cm3 g-1), and exceptionally high uptake capacities for N2, H2, O2, CO2, and CH4 gases.
Control of Interpenetration and Gas-Sorption Properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks by a Simple Change in Ligand Design
Prasad, Thazhe Kootteri; Suh, Myunghyun Paik

In metal-org. framework (MOF) chem., interpenetration greatly affects the gas-sorption properties.  However, there is a lack of a systematic study on how to control the interpenetration and whether the interpenetration enhances gas uptake capacities or not.  The authors report an example of interpenetration that is simply controlled by the presence of a carbon-carbon double or single bond in identical org. building blocks, and provide a comparison of gas-sorption properties for these similar frameworks, which differ only in their degree of interpenetration.  Non-interpenetrated (SNU-70) and doubly interpenetrated (SNU-71) cubic nets were prepd. by a solvothermal reaction of [Zn(NO3)2]·6H2O in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) with 4-(2-carboxyvinyl)benzoic acid and 4-(2-carboxyethyl)benzoic acid, resp.  They have almost identical structures, but the non-interpenetrated framework has a much bigger pore size (ca. 9.0 × 9.0 Å) than the interpenetrated framework (ca. 2.5 × 2.5 Å).  Activation of the MOFs by using supercrit. CO2 gave SNU-70' and SNU-71'.  The simulation of the PXRD pattern of SNU-71' indicates the rearrangement of the interpenetrated networks on guest removal, which increases pore size.  SNU-70' has a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 5290 m2 g-1, which is the highest value reported to date for a MOF with a cubic-net structure, whereas SNU-71' has a BET surface area of 1770 m2 g-1.  In general, non-interpenetrated SNU-70' exhibits much higher gas-adsorption capacities than interpenetrated SNU-71' at high pressures, regardless of the temp.  However, at P < 1 atm, the gas adsorption capacities for N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 195 K are higher for non-interpenetrated SNU-70' than for interpenetrated SNU-71', but the capacities for H2 and CH4 are the opposite; SNU-71' has higher uptake capacities than SNU-70' due to the higher isosteric heat of gas adsorption that results from the smaller pores.  In particular, SNU-70' has exceptionally high H2 and CO2 uptake capacities.  By using a post-synthetic method, the C:C double bond in SNU-70 was quant. brominated at room temp., and the MOF still showed very high porosity (BET surface area of 2285 m2 g-1).

Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Lewis, William; Suyetin, Mikhail; Bichoutskaia, Elena; Parker, Julia E.; Tang, Chiu C.; Allan, David R.; Rizkallah, Pierre J.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Thomas, K. Mark; Blake, Alexander J.; Schroeder, Martin

Selective CO2 capture in porous materials has potential for the storage and treatment of fuel and flue gases; however, adsorption capacities under dynamic conditions are often insufficient for practical applications and strategies to enhance CO2-host selectivity are required.  The unique, partially inter-penetrated metal-org. framework, NOTT-202, represents a new class of dynamic material which undergoes pronounced framework phase transition on desolvation.  This work reports temp.-dependent adsorption/desorption hysteresis in de-solvated NOTT-202a which selectively responds to CO2.  The CO2 isotherm shows 3 steps in the adsorption profile at 195° K; step-wise filling of pores generated within the obsd. partially inter-penetrated structure has been modeled using grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations.  Adsorption of N2, CH4, O2, Ar, and H2 exhibited reversible isotherms without hysteresis under the same conditions, allowing for gas capture at high pressure; but, it selectively leaves CO2 trapped in nano-pores at low pressure.

Li, Jian-Rong; Ma, Yu-Guang; McCarthy, M. Colin; Sculley, Julian; Yu, Jia-Mei; Jeong, Hae-Kwon; Balbuena, Perla B.; Zhou, Hong-Cai

A review.  Reducing anthropogenic CO2 emission and lowering the concn. of greenhouse gases in the atm. has quickly become one of the most urgent environmental issues of our age.  Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is one option for reducing these harmful CO2 emissions.  While a variety of technologies and methods have been developed, the sepn. of CO2 from gas streams is still a crit. issue.  Apart from establishing new techniques, the exploration of capture materials with high sepn. performance and low capital cost are of paramount importance.  Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a new class of cryst. porous materials constructed by metal-contg. nodes bonded to org. bridging ligands hold great potential as adsorbents or membrane materials in gas sepn.  In this paper, we review the research progress (from exptl. results to mol. simulations) in MOFs for CO2 adsorption, storage, and sepns. (adsorptive sepn. and membrane-based sepn.) that are directly related to CO2 capture.
Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.

An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework.  The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons.  Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column.  The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail.  The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated.  The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites.  The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes.  A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.
Evaluating metal-organic frameworks for post-combustion carbon dioxide capture via temperature swing adsorption
Mason, Jarad A.; Sumida, Kenji; Herm, Zoey R.; Krishna, Rajamani; Long, Jeffrey R.

Two representative metal-org. frameworks, Zn4O(BTB)2 (BTB3- = 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoate; MOF-177) and Mg2(dobdc) (dobdc4- = 1,4-dioxido-2,5-benzenedicarboxylate; Mg-MOF-74, CPO-27-Mg), are evaluated in detail for their potential use in post-combustion CO2 capture via temp. swing adsorption (TSA).  Low-pressure single-component CO2 and N2 adsorption isotherms were measured every 10° from 20 to 200°, allowing the performance of each material to be analyzed precisely.  To gain a more complete understanding of the sepn. phenomena and the thermodn. of CO2 adsorption, the isotherms were analyzed using a variety of methods.  With regard to the isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption, Mg2(dobdc) exhibits an abrupt drop at loadings approaching the satn. of the Mg2+ sites, which has significant implications for regeneration in different industrial applications.  The CO2/N2 selectivities were calcd. using ideal adsorbed soln. theory (IAST) for MOF-177, Mg2(dobdc), and zeolite NaX, and working capacities were estd. using a simplified TSA model.  Significantly, MOF-177 fails to exhibit a pos. working capacity even at regeneration temps. ≤200°, while Mg2(dobdc) reaches a working capacity of 17.6% at this temp.  Breakthrough simulations were also performed for the three materials, demonstrating the superior performance of Mg2(dobdc) over MOF-177 and zeolite NaX.  The presence of strong CO2 adsorption sites is essential for a metal-org. framework to be of utility in post-combustion CO2 capture via a TSA process, and present a methodol. for the evaluation of new metal-org. frameworks via anal. of single-component gas adsorption isotherms.
Porous materials with optimal adsorption thermodynamics and kinetics for CO2 separation

Nugent, Patrick; Belmabkhout, Youssef; Burd, Stephen D.; Cairns, Amy J.; Luebke, Ryan; Forrest, Katherine; Pham, Tony; Ma, Shengqian; Space, Brian; Wojtas, Lukasz; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Zaworotko, Michael J.

Energy costs assocd. with the sepn. and purifn. of industrial commodities (e.g., gases, fine chems., fresh water) currently represent ∼15% of global energy prodn.; the demand for such commodities is projected to triple by 2050 (P. Taylor, 2010).  The challenge of developing effective sepn. and purifn. technologies which have much smaller energy footprints is greater for CO2 than for other gases; in addn. to its involvement in climate change, CO2 is an impurity in natural gas, biogas (biomass-based natural gas), syngas (CO/H2, the main H2 source for refineries), and many other gas streams.  In the context of porous cryst. materials which can exploit equil. and kinetic selectivity, size selectivity and targeted mol. recognition are attractive characteristics for CO2 sepn. and capture, as exemplified by 5A and 13X zeolites (J. Merel, et al., 2008), and metal-org. materials (MOM).  This paper reports that a crystal engineering or reticular chem. strategy which controls pore functionality and pore size in a series of MOM with coordinately satd. metal centers and periodically arrayed hexafluorosilicate anions (SiF52-) enables a kinetics and thermodn. sweet spots offering high volumetric uptake at low CO2 partial pressure (<0.15 bar).  Most importantly, such MOM offer an unprecedented CO2 sorption selectivity over N2, H2, and CH4, even in the presence of moisture.  Thus, these MOM are relevant to CO2 sepn. in the context of post-combustion (flue gas, CO2/N2), pre-combustion (shifted synthesis gas stream, CO2/H2), and natural gas upgrading (natural gas clean-up, CO2/CH4).

A CO2 selective dynamic two-dimensional (2D) MOF system, [Zn(glu)(μ-bpe)]·2H2O (1·2H2O) (glu = glutarate, bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene), is prepd.  Based on variable temp. Enantioselective catalysis with homochiral metal-organic frameworks
Ma, Liqing; Abney, Carter; Lin, Wenbin

This tutorial review presents recent developments of homochiral metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) for enantioselective catalysis.  Following a brief introduction of the basic concepts and potential virtues of MOFs in catalysis, three distinct strategies that have been utilized to synthesize homochiral MOFs were summarized.  Framework stability and accessibility of the open channels to reagents were then addressed.  Some recent successful examples of catalytically active homochiral MOFs based on three approaches, namely, homochiral MOFs with achiral catalytic sites, incorporation of asym. catalysts directly into the framework, and post-synthetic modification of homochiral MOFs were finally surveyed.  Although still in their infancy, homochiral MOFs have clearly demonstrated their utility in heterogeneous asym. catalysis, and a bright future is foreseen for the development of practically useful homochiral MOFs in the prodn. of optically pure org. mols.
Homochiral Metal-Organic Frameworks for Asymmetric Heterogeneous Catalysis
Yoon, Minyoung; Srirambalaji, Renganathan; Kim, Kimoon

A review.  The authors have provided an overview of metal-org. framework (MOF)-based asym. heterogeneous catalysis by presenting the state of the art in this field and discussing its potential and limitations. Metal-Organic Frameworks: A Rapidly Growing Class of Versatile Nanoporous Materials
Meek, Scott T.; Greathouse, Jeffery A.; Allendorf, Mark D.

A review.  Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) represent a new class of hybrid org.-inorg. supramol. materials comprised of ordered networks formed from org. electron donor linkers and metal cations.  They can exhibit extremely high surface areas, as well as tunable pore size and functionality, and can act as hosts for a variety of guest mols.  Since their discovery, MOFs have enjoyed extensive exploration, with applications ranging from gas storage to drug delivery to sensing.  This review covers advances in the MOF field from the past three years, focusing on applications, including gas sepn., catalysis, drug delivery, optical and electronic applications, and sensing.  We also summarize recent work on methods for MOF synthesis and computational modeling.
Metal organic frameworks as heterogeneous catalysts for the production of fine chemicals
Dhakshinamoorthy, Amarajothi; Opanasenko, Maksym; Cejka, Jiri; Garcia, Hermenegildo

A review; this review focuses on the use of metal org. frameworks (MOFs) as catalysts for the synthesis of fine chems.  While petrochem. is characterized by gas phase reactions, in which MOFs cannot compete with robust zeolites, MOFs are better suited for liq. phase reactions performed at moderate temps.  These are the conditions typically employed for the prodn. of fine chems. characterized by being more complex and diverse mols. of low volatility, but with high added value.  For the prepn. of this type of compd., MOFs offer the advantage of wide open porosity in the nanometer scale and a large void vol.  In the present review we have summarized the reports that appeared up to early 2013 on the use of MOFs as catalysts in the liq. phase for the prodn. of fine chems., primarily classified according to the type of active site and the functional group formed in the reaction.  Prospects for future development in this field are provided in the last section.

Dhakshinamoorthy, Amarajothi; Alvaro, Mercedes; Corma, Avelino; Garcia, Hermenegildo

A review; this perspective article is aimed at providing a comparison of similarities and dissimilarities between the catalytic properties of zeolites and metal org. frameworks (MOFs).  In the first part of the paper, we comment the general characteristics of MOFs with relevance to catalysis, making emphasis of how the properties of MOFs can serve to compliment those of zeolites as catalysts.  The lower chem. and thermal stability of MOFs compared to zeolites is commented and correlated to the requirements for some liq.-phase reactions conducted under mild conditions.  In the second part, we discuss the behavior of zeolites and MOFs for four types of general org. reactions (acid catalyzed, base catalyzed, oxidn. and hydrogenations). A review.  Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are porous cryst. materials that have promising applications as heterogeneous catalysts.  After describing the compn., textural properties and crystal structure of four com. available MOFs, the authors summarize org. transformations for which these com. MOFs exhibit higher catalytic activity than the corresponding sol. metal salts or metal ion-exchanged zeolites. A review; the role of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) in the field of catalysis is discussed, and special focus is placed on their assets and limits in light of current challenges in catalysis and green chem.  Their structural and dynamic features are presented in terms of catalytic functions along with how MOFs can be designed to bridge the gap between zeolites and enzymes.
